Indicator: Years of Potential Life Lost Before Age 75
dataSource: National Vital Statistics System - Mortality accessed through Health Indicators Warehouse
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
description: Years of Potential Life Lost Before Age 75 (YPLL-75) is an age-adjusted rate per 100,000 of the population. It is based on the average years a person would have lived if he or she had not died before age 75.

Indicator: Poor or Fair Health
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) as reported by County Health Rankings & Roadmaps
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
description: Percentage of adults who rate their health as "fair" or "poor" in response to the question, "In general, would you say that your health is excellent, very good, good, fair, or poor?"

Indicator: Adult Smoking Prevalence
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) as reported by County Health Rankings & Roadmaps
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
description: Percentage of adults who have smoked at least 100 cigarettes in their lifetime and currently smoke "every day" or "some days."

Indicator: Teen Smoking Prevalence, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who smoked on at least one day in the past 30 days.

Indicator: Adult Excessive Drinking
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) as reported by County Health Rankings & Roadmaps
description: Adult excessive drinking is the percentage of adults reporting binge or heavy drinking.
Note: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention define binge drinking as drinking 5 or more drinks on an occasion for men or 4 or more drinks on an occasion for women and heavy drinking as drinking 15 or more drinks per week for men, or 8 or more drinks per week for women. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

Indicator: Teen Binge Drinking, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who had 5 or more alcoholic drinks in a row within a couple hours on at least one day in the past 30 days.

Indicator: Teen Obesity Prevalence, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students with BMI greater than or equal to 95th percentile for their sex and age group.

Indicator: Adult Obesity Prevalence
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System Data as presented in the National Diabetes Surveillance System
description: Percentage of adults with BMI greater than or equal to 30kg/m2, based on self-reported height and weight.
Note: See the overtime graph for the most recent data for Philadelphia.

Indicator: Teens Drinking ≥ 1 Sugary Drink Daily, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who reported that they drank soda at least once a day for past 30 days. Respondents were instructed “Do not count diet soda or diet pop.”
Note: Examples provided to respondents included Coke, 7-Up, Snapple, Hugs, lemonade, and Kool-Aid.

Indicator: Premature Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
dataSource: Interactive Atlas of Heart Disease and Stroke, National Center for Health Statistics
description: Age-adjusted rate per 100,000 persons of CVD deaths (all heart disease) to persons under 75 years of age.
Note: See the overtime graph for the most recent data for Philadelphia.

Indicator: Adult Hypertension Prevalence
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)
description: Percentage of adults who have been told by a doctor or other health professional that they have high blood pressure or hypertension. Excludes respondents with a history of gestational hypertension only.
Note: See the overtime graph for the most recent data for Philadelphia.

Indicator: Adult Diabetes Prevalence
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)
dataSource2: County level data is BRFSS as presented in the National Diabetes Surveillance System
description: Percentage of adults who have been told by a doctor or other health professional that they have or have had diabetes. Excludes respondents with a history of gestational diabetes only.
Note: See the overtime graph for the most recent data for Philadelphia. The nationwide estimate provided by BRFSS is a median of the state and DC estimates.

Indicator: New HIV Diagnoses per 100,000 People
dataSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, HIV Surveillance Report
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): HIV Surveillance Data, AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
description: Rate of new HIV diagnoses per 100,000 population.
Note: See the overtime graph for the most recent data for Philadelphia.

Indicator: Teens Who Used Condom with Last Sexual Encounter, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of sexually active 9th-12th grade students who reported using a condom during their most recent sexual intercourse. Respondents are considered sexually active if they report intercourse with at least one person in the three months preceding the survey.

Indicator: Teens Who Used Birth Control with Last Sexual Encounter, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of sexually active 9th-12th grade students who used some form of birth control during their most recent sexual intercourse. Respondents are considered sexually active if they report intercourse with at least one person in the three months preceding the survey.

Indicator: Teen Births per 1,000 Teens, 15-19 Years of Age
dataSource: National Vital Statistics System - Natality accessed through Health Indicators Warehouse
description: Birth rate per 1,000 teen girls age 15-19 years.

Indicator: Infant Mortality Rate per 1,000 Live Births
dataSource: Linked Birth/Infant Death Data Set accessed through Health Indicators Warehouse
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
description: Mortality rate per 1,000 live-born infants under one year of age.

Indicator: Low Birth Weight Births
dataSource: National Vital Statistics System - Natality accessed through Health Indicators Warehouse
description: Percentage of live-born infants weighing less than 2,500 grams - or 5 pounds 8 ounces - at birth.

Indicator: Children Up to Date on Immunizations, 19-35 Months of Age
dataSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Immunization Survey
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Division of Disease Control, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
description: Percentage of children, age 19-35 months, completing recommended vaccination schedule 4:3:1:3 (DTaP : IPV : MMR : Hib).

Indicator: Child Mortality Rate per 100,000, < 18 Years of Age
dataSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Center for Health Statistics on CDC WONDER Online Database
description: Age-adjusted mortality rate per 100,000 children under 18 years of age.

Indicator: Adults Without Insurance, 18-64 Years of Age
dataSource: US Census Bureau Small Area Health Insurance Estimates
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
description: Percentage of adults, age 18-64 years old, reporting no source of insurance.
Note: Nationwide data is from the US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates, 2014.

Indicator: Children Without Insurance, < 18 Years of Age
dataSource: US Census Bureau Small Area Health Insurance Estimates
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
description: Percentage of children under 18 without health insurance.
Note: Nationwide data is from the US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates, 2014. Small Area Health Insurance Estimates (SAHIE) for counties are based on data from a variety of sources and may not be based on survey data.

Indicator: Adults with Colonoscopy or Sigmoidoscopy in Lifetime, ≥ 50 Years of Age
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
description: Percentage of adults, age 50 years and older, reporting ever having had a colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy.
Note: Philadelphia (local source) data reflect adults 50-74 years of age.

Indicator: Women with Mammography in Past 2 Years, 50+ Years of Age
dataSource: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
description: Percentage of women, age 50 years and older, reporting having had a mammogram in the past 2 years.
Note: Philadelphia (local source) data reflect women 50-74 years of age.

Indicator: Girls Completing 3-Dose HPV Vaccine, 13-17 Years of Age
dataSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Immunization Survey
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Division of Disease Control, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
description: Percentage of girls, age 13-17 years, who received 3 doses of HPV vaccine out of all girls, age 13-17 years, in the respective population.
Note: Philadelphia (local source) data are based on local reporting of immunizations provided by clinicians, and some underreporting for adolescents may occur. Data from the National Immunization Survey are based on self-report and may overestimate immunization rates.

Indicator: Boys Completing 3-Dose HPV Vaccine, 13-17 Years of Age
dataSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Immunization Survey
description: Percentage of boys, age 13-17 years, who received 3 doses of HPV vaccine out of all boys, age 13-17 years, in the respective population.
Note: Data from the National Immunization Survey are based on self-report and may overestimate immunization rates.

Indicator: Violent Crime Rate per 100,000 People
dataSource: FBI Uniform Crime Reports
description: Rate per 100,000 persons of reported violent crimes, including murders and non-negligent manslaughters, forcible rapes, robberies, and aggravated assaults.

Indicator: Homicide Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
dataSource: FBI Uniform Crime Reports
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): Medical Examiner's Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
description: Rate of homicide deaths per 100,000 persons.

Indicator: Teens Considering Suicide in the Past Year, 9th-12th Grade
dataSource: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
description: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who seriously considered attempting suicide in the past 12 months.

Indicator: Advanced or Proficient Reading Skills in 4th Grade
dataSource: National Center for Education Statistics, National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), Reading Assessment
description: Percentage of students in 4th grade scoring at the proficient or advanced level on the 4th grade reading assessment.
Note: National and county data are not available for 3rd grade: using 4th grade as a substitute. City data are from the urban school districts program of NAEP, called Trial Urban District Assessment (TUDA).

Indicator: On-Time High School Graduation
dataSource: US Department of Education EdFacts as reported by County Health Rankings & Roadmaps
dataSource2: Philadelphia (local source): School District of Philadelphia
description: Percentage of all students who graduate from high school within four years after starting 9th grade.
Note: Nationwide data is from the National Center for Education Statistics, Common Core of Data.

Indicator: Adults Completing Some College, ≥ 25 Years of Age
dataSource: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
description: Percentage of adults, 25 years or older, who completed at least some college.
Note: Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

Indicator: Unemployment, ≥ 16 Years of Age
dataSource: Bureau of Labor Statistics
description: Percentage of population, 16 years or older, who are unemployed but seeking work.
Note: Please note that data sources and years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

Indicator: People Living in Poverty
dataSource: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
description: Percentage of population, including all ages, living in a household with an income below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL).
Note: In 2014, the FPL was equivalent to a yearly income of no more than $11,670 for an individual, or $23,850 for a family of 4. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

Indicator: Children Living in Poverty, < 18 Years of Age
dataSource: US Census Bureau, Small Area Income and Poverty Estimates
description: Percentage of children under 18 with a family income below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL).
Note: In 2014, the FPL was equivalent to a yearly income of no more than $11,670 for an individual, or $23,850 for a family of 4. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

Indicator: Children in Single-Parent Households, < 18 Years of Age
dataSource: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
description: Percentage of all children in family households that live in a household headed by a single parent (male or female head of household with no spouse present).

Indicator: Housing-Cost Burden for Renters
dataSource: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
description: Percentage of the household population who pays 30% or more of their income for rental housing.
Note: According to the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), families who pay more than 30% of their income for housing are considered cost burdened and may have difficulty affording necessities such as food, clothing, transportation, and medical care.

Indicator: Severe Housing-Cost Burden for Renters
dataSource: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
description: Percentage of the household population who pays 50% or more of their income for rental housing.
Note: According to the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), families who pay more than 30% of their income for housing are considered cost burdened and may have difficulty affording necessities such as food, clothing, transportation, and medical care.
